Joint School of National University of Singapore and Tianjin University International Campus of Tianjin University Binhai New City Fuzhou 350207 China Graphical abstract Identification the size dependence behavior of copper active species are crucial for achieving semi-hydrogenation of carbon–oxygen bonds in the symmetric-structured molecules. Semi-hydrogenation of dimethyl oxalate (DMO) was used as typical for investigation, providing a promising pathway for the production of methyl glycolate (MG), an important feedstock for high value-added materials. Here, by employing a theoretical study, we elucidated the structure-sensitivity and emphasized the vital role of electronic and geometric structure in the reaction mechanism over Cun/CeO2 catalysts. The Cu4 cluster with a “ridge-like” structure and dual sites (Cu0-Cuδ+) exhibited the best performance for semi-hydrogenation of DMO to MG, agreed with the experimental results. Electronic structure of small Cu clusters influences MG selectivity by affecting the strength of donor–acceptor interactions between empty d orbitals of Cu and the π orbitals of CO group. In contrast, steric hindrance induces a downward-directed configuration of acyl species on larger Cu clusters, reducing the Pauli repulsion in the transition state of MG dissociation, and promoting undesired further hydrogenation of MG. Our findings provided a rational guideline for designing catalysts with optimal particle size and morphology in the semi-hydrogenation of symmetric-structured molecules. Keywords Selective hydrogenation Cu cluster Size-dependent Active site DFT Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Semi-hydrogenation of molecules with symmetric structure plays a crucial role in the production of fine chemicals, pharmaceuticals, and agrochemicals [1–3]. Specially, the high-selectivity conversion of compounds with oxygen-containing functional groups to valuable unsaturated products is essential to meet the growing demand in chemical industry [4,5]. Copper-based catalysts exhibit unique advantage in selective hydrogenation of carbon–oxygen bonds, as it remaining inactive towards CC cleavage [6–8]. It is usually exhibited excellent activity in hydrogenating CO/CO bonds, whereas the realization of high chemoselectivity is increasingly challenging particularly in the semi-hydrogenation of a symmetric structure molecule [9,10]. In this context, we chose the dimethyl oxalate (DMO) with a symmetric diester structure as typical reactant for investigation. The semi-hydrogenation of DMO to methyl glycolate (MG) has drawn much attention, which contains both hydroxyl and ester groups and is utilized as the feedstock in producing high value-added-materials like biodegradable polymers, detergents, dyes, etc. [11–13]. However, the further hydrogenation of MG to ethylene glycol (EG) always occurs, especially at high conversions of DMO, because its reaction rate constant on commercial Cu/SiO2 catalysts is 2 times greater than that for DMO hydrogenation to MG [14], leading to the decreased yield of MG and extensively enhanced cost for product purification. Changing the support to such as CeO2 [15], reduced graphene oxide (rGO) [16], active carbon [17], etc. or using them as dopants was the general approach to modulate the selectivity in the hydrogenation of DMO, which essentially regulated the electronic and geometric properties of surface copper species. Current research demonstrated that copper active species are composed of Cu0 and Cuδ+(0 < δ ≤ 1) sites, with Cu0 sites facilitating hydrogen adsorption and dissociation, while Cuδ+ activate ester molecules [18]. A series of rGO-supported catalysts were prepared with various shaped copper species from ultra-small dots to leaf-like nanoparticles, and it is demonstrated that the size and shape of copper greatly influenced the product distribution [19]. We recently engineered the size of Cu from single-atom, sub-nanometer clusters to nanoparticles via a low-temperature atomic migration strategy, where copper species over SiO2 transferred to CeO2 under 200 °C. As-prepared Cu3 clusters with balanced MG adsorption and H2 dissociation capability, achieved 95 % selectivity toward MG at almost 100 % conversion of DMO [20]. The C60 modulated single-atom Cu and Cu4 clusters were investigated by theoretical study and found that the higher oxidation state of Cu1 could promote the MG selectivity by increasing the barrier for further hydrogenation of MG to EG [21,22]. But when discussing the single-atom Cu supported by different materials, it is suggested that the weaker copper-support interaction, the lower oxidation state of Cu1, the higher selectivity of MG [23]. Hence, it is clearly demonstrated that the size, shape as well as the chemical state of copper species significantly manipulated the chemoselectivity in the DMO hydrogenation, but how these variables intimately linked to the efficient and selective catalysis is ambiguous. Vital gaps remain in understanding the catalytic mechanism and clarifying the electronic and geometric effects in size-dependence over copper species. Herein, we built theoretical catalyst models of Cun/CeO2(111) (n = 1–8, 14) and Cu(111) to investigate the size-dependence over active sites in the DMO hydrogenation, combining density functional theory (DFT) calculations and microkinetic simulations. The synergistic catalysis between Cu0 and Cuδ+ facilitates the progression of DMO hydrogenation and plays a crucial role in the variations of adsorption configurations for intermediates throughout the entire catalytic process. And it is uncovered a distinctive volcano-shaped relationship between the selectivity of MG and the size of copper species. The electronic effect is particularly significant in MG adsorption for small copper species, where the work function is negatively correlated with the MG selectivity. However, the steric hindrance induces downward-directed adsorption configuration of acyl group on larger Cu clusters, where the undesired hydrogenation of MG preferentially occurs due to the reduced Pauli repulsion between methoxy and acyl species. The Cu0-Cuδ+ dual-site exposed by clusters of ridge-like morphology is identified as the optimal Cu/CeO2 configuration for DMO semi-hydrogenation, consistent with the experimental results. These findings could guide the design of supported Cu-based catalysts with unique chemoselectivity in the hydrogenation of molecules with symmetric structure. 2 Computational details 2.1 Methods All the calculations were performed by using the Vienna ab initio simulation package (VASP) program with the spin-polarization being considered [24,25]. The exchange and correlation energy was calculated by the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) functional within the generalized gradient approximation (GGA), and potentials within the projector augmented wave method (PAW) were used to represent the core-valence electron interaction [26,27]. A cutoff energy of 400 eV was found to give converged results. The geometry optimization was stopped when the energy difference and the force residue on the atom are smaller than 10−5 eV and 0.03 eV A−1, respectively. The Ueff values of 4.5 eV (Ueff = U-J) [28] for the Ce atoms is suitable for the description of 4f electrons. The transition states (TSs) of elementary steps were identified by combining the climbing-image nudged elastic band (CI-NEB) and dimer method [29,30]. The weak interaction was considered by using the DFT-D3 method for adsorption behaviors [31]. The Gibbs free energy including zero-point energy (ZPE), internal energy and entropy were calculated for the whole DMO hydrogenation to compare with the results more directly under experimental condition. Catalysis Microkinetic Analysis Package (CatMAP) was used to perform microkinetic modeling by according to the mean-field assumption [32]. The calculation details can be found in the Supplementary Information. 2.2 Models The optimized lattice for bulk CeO2 (5.48 Å) agree well with the experimental data (5.49 Å) [33]. Campbell et al. found that the catalytic system tends to be unstable when copper atoms bind near oxygen vacancies on the CeO2 surface [34]. And in situ Raman spectroscopy studies by Hess et al. indicated that the reduction degree of CeO2 is not directly related to its reactivity and may even exhibit a negative correlation [35]. In addition, previous research has indicated that Cu0-Cuδ+ species rather than oxygen vacancies and Cu-[Ox]-Ce are the primary active sites for ester hydrogenation [36]. Based on these experimental findings, the most stable facet CeO2(111) surface of p(3 × 3) super cell without oxygen-vacancy was selected for Cu cluster deposition. The model consists of three layers of Ce atoms and six layers of O atoms and the vacuum space of 15 Å was used to minimize the interactions between the periodically repeated crystal faces. All atoms in the bottom O-Ce-O trilayers were fixed whereas the rest of the atoms were relaxed during geometry optimization. AIMD simulation was performed to search for optimal structures in the canonical (NVT) ensemble employing Nosé-Hoover thermostats at 473 K for 5000 fs with 1 fs time step, to agree with the experimental condition [20]. A four-layer slabs of Cu(111) was denoted to larger size of particle, which the bottom two layers were frozen and other layers was left free to relax. To further validate the impact of the number of k-point on the calculation results, we calculated the adsorption energies of species using 1 × 1 × 1 and 2 × 2 × 1 k-point mesh, respectively, for cluster models. As shown in Table S1, the k-point mesh converged the adsorption energy of species within 0.03 eV with respect to the k-point mesh change (1 × 1 × 1 → 2 × 2 × 1). Thus, taking both computational cost and accuracy into consideration, Brillouin zone sampling was done by using Monkhorst-Pack meshes with the k-points being set to 1 × 1 × 1 for Cun/CeO2(111) (n = 1–8 and 14) models, while 3 × 3 × 1 k-point was used for Cu(111). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Models for the Cun/CeO2(111) (n = 1–8 and 14) composites The initial structures of Cun cluster (n = 1–8 and 14) were derived from the high-symmetry stable configuration in the gas phase, including both two-dimensional and three-dimensional clusters [37,38], which were positioned over CeO2(111) to maximize their interaction with oxygen atoms due to the oxyphilic nature of Cu. As shown in Fig. 1 a–b and Table S2, the Cu1 to Cu3 clusters demonstrated a one-layer structure bound to the CeO2(111) surface via CuO bonds, of which vertical heights were less than 0.7 Å. The Cu4 to Cu8 clusters all preferred a two-layer structure but their top layer configurations were different. The Cu4 to Cu6 clusters exhibited a ridge-like configuration with the coordination number (CN) of top-layer Cu of 3–4, while that became a platform with a higher CN of 4–5 in Cu7 and Cu8 clusters, resulting in the slightly increased height of about 0.3 Å. Apparently, Cu4-6 clusters with ridge-like configurations are more likely to be a transition form between one-layer and two-layer Cu clusters. Then, the Cu1, Cu4, Cu8 clusters can be used as the representative geometric structures of one to two Cu layers and we further enlarged the size to Cu14 cluster of three-layer architecture with a ∼5.12 Å height. It is worthy to mention that most of Cu atoms on the top layer of Cu14 cluster possessed the CN of 5, as the same as those on the Cu8 cluster. And the Cu atoms in the bottom layer are of similar coordination environments across different configurations with two- or three-layered structures. In addition, the ceria support played a crucial role in stabilizing Cu clusters. The CuCu bond lengths in the Cun/CeO2(111) are shortened from 2.56 Å to a range of 2.29 Å–2.54 Å compared to the bulk metallic copper, meanwhile, both the binding energies and cohesive energies are promoted as the increasing number of copper atoms (Fig. 1c). This explains why the metal nanoclusters showed significantly different properties from the bulk metal and why their reactivity, when supported on metal oxides, often surpassed that of the bulk active metal [39]. In Fig. 1b, we also analyzed the Bader charge and difference charge density for the Cun clusters in order to compare their electronic structures. It is indicated that all interface Cu atoms in the clusters become positively charged upon deposited on the CeO2(111) surface, while the other Cu atoms in Cun/CeO2(111) (n ≥ 4) are nearly charge-neutral and exhibit an electronic structure similar to that of bulk metallic copper. It should be pointed out that the Cu atom in Cu1/CeO2(111) is positively charged by +0.68 |e|, showing the strongest electron-deficient character [40]. In contrast, the interfacial Cu atoms in other Cun/CeO2(111) (n ≥ 2) carry the similar positive charge ranging from +0.21 to +0.35 |e|, attributed to their consistent CuO coordination environment. The observed trend for Bader charge transfer is agreed with the calculation results of charge density difference, as indicated by the yellow-colored region in Figs. S1–S2. It is demonstrated that the electron density is shared between the interfacial Cu (electron donors) and lattice O (electron acceptors) atoms, leading to hybridization between Cu-3d and O-2p orbitals and the formation of a strong covalent-like bond. Considering the similarity in the electronic and geometric structures, and the fact that the active sites for esters hydrogenation have been reported to reside at Cu0-Cuδ+ interfacial dual sites, we conducted the reaction mechanism calculations on Cu1/CeO2(111), Cu4/CeO2(111), Cu8/CeO2(111) and Cu(111). Meanwhile, AIMD simulations were carried out to examine the thermodynamic stability of these models at the experiment temperature of 473 K [20] as exhibited in Fig. S3. It is generally accepted that the reaction mechanisms of DMO hydrogenation to MG and EG include the direct hydrogenation pathways (A and D) and the dissociation pathways (B and C) in Fig. 1d [41,42]. The dissociation pathway is that CO bond adjacent to the carbonyl group is first broken to yield adsorbed acyl and methoxyl groups before the further hydrogenation. In the direct hydrogenation mechanism, the direct attack of H atoms on carbonyl groups leading to the formation of alcohol hydroxyl groups, and the intermediate species undergoes further hydrogenation and dissociates into alcohol and methoxyl groups. The intermediates are subsequently converted to MG and methanol, respectively and the obtained MG either desorbs from the catalyst surface or further hydrogenated to produce EG and methanol. 3.2 Mechanistic insights into DMO hydrogenation on Cun/CeO2(111) (n = 1, 4, 8) and Cu(111) catalysts Fig. S4 summarized the possible adsorption configurations and the corresponding adsorption energies of DMO, MG, EG and CH3OH species on the Cun/CeO2(111) (n = 1, 4, 8) and Cu(111) catalysts. Since Cu(111) is a typical flat surface model, the adsorption of both reactants and products is weak. On the Cu1/CeO2(111) model, the DMO molecule bind to the single atom Cu site via the oxygen atoms of its CO and CO groups. For Cu4 and Cu8 clusters, the most stable adsorption configuration is observed at the Cu0-Cuδ+ interface, where the O (CO group) of one ester group coordinates with the Cu0 site, and O (CO group) of the other ester group is aligned toward the neighbor Cuδ+ site. It should be pointed out that although MG contains both CO and OH groups, the O (CO group) preferentially coordinates with the Cu0 site on Cu4/CeO2(111) and Cu8/CeO2(111) catalysts with a higher adsorption energy compared to binding on Cuδ+ site, which displaying a consistent pattern on the Cu5–7,14/CeO2(111) models (Fig. S5). Notably, the second-layer step site on the Cu14 cluster was the most stable adsorption site, and this site is located near the metal-support interface. Similarly, the most stable adsorption configurations of EG and CH3OH are observed at Cu0 sites. In particular, DMO exhibits a higher adsorption energy compared to MG in all the catalyst systems but Cu1/CeO2(111), because the hydroxyl group in MG is strongly bind to CeO2 surface in the Cu1 system [43]. Given the presence of steric hindrance, it is not surprising that the CO group of ester molecule interact readily to Cu0 site. However, it is generally accepted that the Cu0 sites primarily facilitate the H2 dissociation, while Cuδ+ species promote the methoxy or acyl species adsorption and activation over the Cu-based catalysts during ester hydrogenation [44]. Thus, the synergy in catalysis between Cu0 and Cuδ+ species should be further clarify. The catalytic mechanism, possible elementary steps for the DMO/MG subsequent hydrogenation are investigated. First, H atoms produced from H2 dissociation play an essential role in DMO hydrogenation. The optimized structures are presented in Fig. S6. It is indicated that H2 dissociates heterolytically on Cu1/CeO2 with H atoms splitting between the Cu atom and the lattice oxygen, whereas H2 is preferentially activated on Cu0 via a homolytic cleavage mechanism on Cu4, Cu8 clusters and Cu(111) [45]. Gibbs free energy diagrams for the direct hydrogenation and dissociation mechanisms on the Cun/CeO2(111) and Cu(111) models are displayed in Figs. S7–S10. In the direct hydrogenation, the elementary step where a H atom attacks the O (CO group) of ester molecules (DMO and MG) is of highest activation energy for the supported Cu clusters except for the Cu8 system. Over the Cu8/CeO2(111), the hydrogenation of CH3O* species to methanol exhibits the highest barriers, but it occurs on Cu0 sites and doesn’t inhibit the production of MG and EG. Thus, the primary elementary hydrogenation step of DMO/MG is identified as the rate-determining step over the Cun/CeO2(111), a conclusion further confirmed by microkinetic simulation, which reveal that the energy barriers decrease with increasing cluster size. As for Cu(111) surface, the dissociation of the intermediate species is the rate-determining step. It is worthy mentioned that the primary hydrogenation barrier of MG is consistently higher than that of DMO, probably originated from the differences in their adsorption configurations. The dual-ester-group adsorption of DMO promotes the attack by H atoms, thereby lowering the hydrogenation barrier. In the dissociation mechanism shown in Fig. 2 a–b, it is demonstrated that the co-adsorption of the acyl and CH3O* species on the single Cu atom destabilizes the transition state over the Cu1 system. On the Cu4 and Cu8 catalysts, DMO dissociation exhibits similar barriers, but the dissociation barrier of MG on Cu4 is 0.87 eV higher than that on Cu8, indicating the possible lower selectivity of MG on Cu8/CeO2(111). Instead of desorbing from the Cu4 surface, the produced MG tends to undergo further hydrogenation. To find out the reason of this difference on MG dissociation barrier over the Cu4 and Cu8, we compared the initial, transition and final states in Fig. 2c. In the initial states, MG molecules both adsorb onto the Cu0 sites through the CO groups, whereas the configurations in the subsequent transition and final states show significant directional differences, further analyzed in the following part. As to the DMO molecules, the dissociation adsorption configurations over the Cu4 and Cu8 are similar, which is the co-adsorbed ester groups onto the Cu0-Cuδ+ sites in a bidentate type. One aspect is that the dissociation of esters is the rate-determining step, and the associated energy barriers can be effectively reduced by catalysts featuring dual active sites (Cu0-Cuδ+), consistent with previous findings. For instance, Sun et al. demonstrated that the dissociation of DMO and MG molecules exhibits the highest Gibbs free energy values (ΔG# values) along reaction pathways B and C [42]. On the Cu5/SiO2 surface, the dissociation of esters serves as the rate-determining step in the most favorable elementary pathway for DMO hydrogenation to EG. Furthermore, it has been shown that intermediate hydrogenation at the Cu0-Cuδ+ interfacial sites possesses lower energy barriers compared to those on Cu(111) and Cu2O(111) [46]. Alternatively, it can be concluded that the dissociation pathway is kinetically and thermodynamically more favorable than the direct hydrogenation pathway [44]. An et al. observed that the energy barriers associated with the rate-determining steps of the direct hydrogenation mechanism exceed 2 eV on Cu2O(111) (representing perfect Cu+), Cu(111) (representing Cu0), as well as on Cu+-defected and mixed Cu0/Cu+ surfaces [47]. Similarly, studies on Cu6/TiO2 catalysts have shown that the energy barriers for DMO direct hydrogenation steps via the non-dissociation mechanism are significantly higher than those for the dissociative adsorption of DMO [48]. All the elementary reaction steps along with the corresponding activation energies and reaction energies, excluding those of the adsorption and desorption of gases, are tabulated in Tables S3 and S4. In the dual-site catalysts, it is worth noting that the synergistic catalysis between Cu0 and Cuδ+ plays a critical role in facilitating the reaction process [49]. Fig. 3 a–b summarize the optimized structures and corresponding coordination configurations of intermediates in the DMO/MG hydrogenation on Cu4/CeO2 and Cu8/CeO2. In Fig. 3a, for the hydrogenation of diesters to monoesters (DMO to MG), no matter following the direct hydrogenation mechanism or the dissociation mechanism, the formation of intermediate CH3OOCCHOH* before MG* production relies on the synergy of Cu0-Cuδ+ dual active sites. In this process, the unsaturated carbon in the acyl group adsorbs onto the Cuδ+ site, while the oxygen in the CH3O* and the other ester group adsorb onto the Cu0 sites, resulting in the formed MG* and CH3OH* are stably adsorbed on the Cu0 sites during following hydrogenation. Nevertheless, the intermediate adsorption sites changed in the subsequent hydrogenation of MG to EG (Fig. 3b). The MG molecule adsorbed on the Cu0 site hydrogenated to the intermediate CH2OHCOHOCH3* in the direct hydrogenation mechanism, where the unsaturated carbon atom binds to Cuδ+ site and the oxygen in methoxy group binds to Cu0 site. Further hydrogenation saturates the carbon atom to generate CH2OHCHOHOCH3*, leaving the O in methoxy adsorbed on Cu0 site. As it further undergoes cleavage to yield CH2OHCHOH* and CH3O*, the unsaturated carbon in the alcohol intermediate adsorbs exclusively onto the Cuδ+ site. In the dissociation mechanism, MG* splits into acyl and CH3O* species, which adsorb on Cuδ+ and Cu0 sites respectively. Subsequent intermediates in the acyl hydrogenation also bind to the Cuδ+ site. Regardless of the mechanism, obtained EG always stably adsorb onto the Cu0 site. It can be concluded that on the dual-site catalysts, Cu0 is responsible for H2 activation, methoxy hydrogenation and reactants/products adsorption, while Cuδ+ facilitates acyl species hydrogenation. Their synergistic catalysis promotes the progression of DMO hydrogenation reaction. 3.3 Catalytic performance of Cun/CeO2(111) (n = 1, 4, 8) and Cu(111) catalysts in the DMO hydrogenation We further conducted microkinetic simulations to investigate the intrinsic kinetic of DMO hydrogenation and the obtained heat maps of TOF rates listed in Figs. S11–S13 and Table S5. It is demonstrated that the dissociation mechanism is kinetically more favorable than the direct hydrogenation mechanism, and the production rates of MG and EG are primarily originated from the contributions from dissociation pathway, consistent with the DFT results. It should be pointed out that the supported Cu clusters effectively enhanced catalytic performance for DMO hydrogenation, and their TOFs of MG and EG followed the order of Cu8/CeO2(111) > Cu4/CeO2(111) > Cu1/CeO2(111) > Cu(111). As shown in Fig. 3c–d, the MG formation dominates on Cu1/CeO2 and Cu4/CeO2, whereas the selectivity of EG increases on Cu8/CeO2 and Cu(111). This is associated with the higher dissociation barriers of MG on Cu1 and Cu4 than those of DMO, whereas an opposite trend exists on the other two catalysts. The selectivity of MG follows a volcano-shaped curve as the copper size increases, which peaks at the Cu4/CeO2 catalyst reaching up to 91 %. The difference in selectively of MG on Cu1 and Cu4 models can be ascribed to the discrepancy in the adsorption energy of MG. For the Cu(111), both DMO and MG exhibit weak adsorption, and the dissociation barrier of MG is lower than that of DMO, making a low activity and the predominant product of EG. Experimentally, under 100 % DMO conversion, the Cu3/CeO2-SiO2 catalyst achieved a maximum MG selectivity of 95 %, which is agreement with the theoretical value of 91 % predicted for the Cu4 cluster model. Moreover, a notable decline in MG selectivity to 68 % as the Cu particle size increased to sub-nanometer clusters, corresponding well with the simulated selectivity of 58.6 % for the Cu8 cluster model. We also calculated the apparent activation energy of DMO hydrogenation to MG (Fig. S11b). The Arrhenius plot of the TOFs for MG all demonstrate a linear relationship with the increasing reaction temperature, and the value of apparent activation energy for Cu(111) is very close to the experimental result reported by Zheng et al. on the Cu/SiO2 catalyst [21], which confirmed the accuracy of calculations. Notably, the apparent activation energies for selective hydrogenation of DMO to MG on the Cu4 and Cu8 clusters are significantly lower than those on the Cu1 and Cu(111) surfaces. It is implied that a crucial aspect lies in the kinetics influenced by the competition between desorption of MG and its subsequent hydrogenation. In principle, when the energy for MG desorption is higher than that for the subsequent hydrogenation, MG molecules tend to remain adsorbed on the catalyst surface and undergo further hydrogenation, resulting in the formation of EG. Conversely, if the barriers of MG hydrogenation are higher, there is an increased propensity for MG desorption, thereby amplifying the selectivity towards MG. Similar perspectives have been observed in other selective hydrogenations as well [50,51]. It is reported that the difference (ΔE) between the barrier for MG hydrogenation and the desorption energy of MG can be used as a descriptor for MG selectivity [23]. Considering the results of reaction mechanism and microkinetic simulations, we further calculated the adsorption of MG and the rate-determining step in dissociative pathway: MG*→CH2OHCO*+CH3O* on the rest Cun/CeO2(111) (n = 2, 3, 5, 7 and 14) models (Table S4). In Fig. 3e, the ΔE on the supported cluster catalysts exhibits a volcano-shaped trend change, aligning with the MG selectivity obtained by microkinetic simulation. It is revealed that the size of Cu clusters can manipulate the values of ΔE, significantly influencing the catalyst performance in the DMO selective hydrogenation to MG. 3.4 Electronic and geometric analysis of Cun/CeO2(111) (n = 1, 4, 8) catalysts for DMO hydrogenation To gain further insights into the size dependence of copper active sites, we investigated the electronic and geometric structures of all these Cun/CeO2(111) models. It is found that the electrons transferred from the interfacial Cu atom to CeO2, of which amount first decreases and then remain nearly constant as the cluster size increases, resulting in the changed electronic structure of Cuδ+ sites. And the magnitude and direction of the charge transfer are driven by the differences between the Fermi level of Cu-clusters and CeO2 surface, ultimately seeking equilibrium of the electron chemical potentials. Work function (Wf) is well-accepted indication to predict charge transfer at interfaces of a hybrid [52]. The Wf values of Cun/CeO2 (n = 1–8 and 14) surfaces were calculated in Fig. 4 a, which significantly affected by the Cu-cluster sizes and consistent with the charge density calculations. The shift in the work-function significantly impacts the adsorption behavior of MG. For the large Wf of catalyst with relatively high oxidation state of Cuδ+ sites, e.g. the Cu1 system, the d band is occupied only up to approximately the top of the nonbonding region. This leaves empty Cu-d orbitals, on average antibonding between nearest neighbors, to participate in strong donation bonding with the CO orbitals. There is a distinct propensity for Cuδ+ to gain (back-donate) more charge or, at least, for Cu to loss less charge from the molecules [53]. This feature is related with the electroaffinity and nucleophilicity of the electron donor–acceptor. As a result, Cu1/CeO2 has the highest MG adsorption energy of −1.55 eV, which may also be contributed by the formation of a weak hydrogen bond between the hydroxyl group of MG and the lattice oxygen on the CeO2 surface. Our calculations also confirm that Cuδ+ sites can enhance the adsorption of ester molecules, in agreement with previous studies [14,22], but considering the steric hindrance, the most stable adsorption sites for MG is Cu0 over the Cu4-8 and Cu14 clusters. The Cu0 site is electron-rich, with the 3d orbitals fully occupied, leaving no suitable vacant d orbitals to stabilize the 2π* orbital. Consequently, the adsorption energy of MG on multilayer cluster catalysts is almost identical [54]. The integrated crystal orbital Hamilton population (ICOHP) analysis [55] was carried out to understand the differences of MG adsorption between the Cu1/CeO2, Cu2/CeO2 and Cu3/CeO2 from a chemical bond perspective. Fig. 4b shows the negative projected COHP (−pCOHP) curves for the bonding strengths and contributions between the Cu atom and the O (CO group) in MG molecular. The positive −pCOHP can be viewed as a bonding interaction, and the negative −pCOHP is regarded as an antibonding interaction. In the case of Cu3/CeO2, it is seen that a significant portion of the antibonding orbitals with negative −pCOHP values is below the Fermi level, weakening the bonding between Cu and O and resulting in a smaller MG adsorption energy than those on the Cu1 and Cu2 systems [56]. It is further supported by the small (absolute-value-wise) integrated ICOHP value of −0.44 between the two atoms. The inset curves in Fig. 4b represent the bonding situation between the C-2p and O-2p orbitals in the CO bond. Some of the O-2p electrons transferred to the Cu atoms, weakening the π bond of MG adsorbed on Cun/CeO2 (n = 1, 2, 3) surfaces. The CO binding orbitals all primarily resided below the Fermi level, and the similar occupancy of the antibonding orbitals indicates a comparable weakening effect on the CO bond, verified by the comparable energy barriers observed for MG dissociation on these three catalysts (Fig. S14). Specifically, the transition state of C-O dissociation for MG on Cu1/CeO2 is only 0.25 eV higher than that on Cu3/CeO2 but the difference in the adsorption energy is as large as 0.60 eV. Thus, it is demonstrated that the magnitude of ΔE for the single-layer clusters systems (Cu1, Cu2 and Cu3) was reflected the significant influence of MG adsorption on its selectivity. Notably, the structure of MG in the adsorption states and the corresponding adsorption energies are nearly unchanged over the cluster catalysts from Cu4 to Cu14. In contrast, significant differences are observed in the activation energies for MG dissociation. Considering the fact that the charge transfer between the interfacial Cu atoms and support in the Cu4-8/CeO2 and Cu14/CeO2, as well as the negligible change in the work function, the shape and morphology of the clusters are possibly the intrinsic factors responsible for the variation in activation energy during MG dissociation. We further utilized the energy decomposition method to analyze the interactions between CH3O* and CH2OHCO* on Cu4-8 and Cu14 clusters, achieving the E int TS (Fig. 4c and Table S6) which is denoted as a quantitative measure of the geometrical effect on catalytic reactions [57]. It could be observed that the E int TS is linearly related with the activation energy of MG dissociation. Generally, E int TS contains mainly two components, i.e. the energy cost from the bonding competition effect and the direct Pauli repulsion. In this case, the energy cost from the bonding competition effect is quite similar due to the separated adsorption of CH3O* and CH2OHCO* on Cu0 and Cuδ+ sites. Then the E int TS , that is, the geometrical effect, is dominantly determined by the Pauli repulsion over the cluster catalysts from Cu4 to Cu14, which is mainly dependent on the distance between two reactants. During MG dissociation, the CO distance increase from 1.90 Å to 2.12 Å as the cluster size enlarges from Cu4 to Cu14, leading to a reduction of the dissociation barrier by 0.92 eV (the inset in Fig. 4c). It is noticed that the strength of absorption energy of the acyl group ( E C H 2 O H C O ∗ TS ) in transition state structure changed a lot when the morphology of Cu clusters varied. The catalyst transitions from a ridge-like morphology to a platform-like morphology as the cluster size increases. The platform structure induced a downward-directed adsorption configuration of CH2OHCO*, attributed to the steric hindrance between the CH2 group and Cu-cluster, thus exhibiting a higher adsorption energy compared to the up-directed adsorption configuration on ridge-like clusters. To explain the acyl groups adsorption with different orientations on Cu4/CeO2 and Cu8/CeO2, LDOS analysis was employed to investigate the interactions between Cu0-Cuδ+-3d orbitals and C-2p orbitals of acyl species as shown in Fig. S15. In addition to the strong interactions between Cuδ+-3d and C-2p, a notable interaction is observed between Cu0-3d and C-2p orbitals on the Cu8 cluster, manifesting as an increased number of spikes and enhanced overlap of peak area. It is also supported by Li and co-workers [58], who reported that the downward-directed configuration can lower the kinetic barrier for the acyl species hydrogenation and thus improve the catalytic performance. The different directional adsorption configurations of CH3O* and CH2OHCO* on Cu0 and Cuδ+ sites also resolved their covalent bonding properties, as illustrated by the electron density difference and electron localized function (ELF) [59] in Fig. 4d. The electron density difference maps show that electrons accumulate around the CH3O* group, exhibiting strong adsorption on Cu0 due to significant electron transfer, whereas electrons are depleted around the acyl group, leading to its weaker adsorption on Cuδ+. Meanwhile, the acyl species process greater electron depletion on the Cu8 and Cu14 clusters than Cu4 system, corresponding to stronger adsorption interactions, in agreement with the trends of adsorption energy listed in Table S6. And in the ELF map of Cu4/CeO2, there is a significant increase in electron density between the CH3O* and CH2OHCO* compared to those on Cu8 and Cu14 clusters, indicating a stronger covalent bonding between the O and C atoms in transition state. It is indicated that the transition state structure for MG dissociation on the Cu4 catalyst is closer to the reactant, while for Cu8 and Cu14, the transition state is closer to the product. MG dissociation on these three catalysts is an endothermic reaction, with respective energy absorptions of 0.16, 0.17, and 0.19 eV, respectively. According to the Hammond postulate [60], as the energy of the product is higher than that of the reactant, a transition state structure closer to the product corresponds to a lower activation energy barrier in an endothermic reaction. Based on the above analysis, it can be concluded that the platform-like morphology of clusters induces a downward-directed acyl adsorption configuration through a steric hindrance between the Cu and CH2OH group, thereby reducing the Pauli repulsion between the CH3O* and CH2OHCO* groups, and lowering the MG dissociation barrier. 3.5 Size dependence of copper on the catalytic performance Our results are consistent with size-dependence of Cu clusters supported on CeO2, where the yield of MG exhibited a volcano-shaped curve with the increasing Cu cluster sizes [20]. We also provide a deep explanation for why the smaller Cu clusters achieved the highest MG yield, attributing it to their balanced adsorption and activation of intermediates at active sites. It is also aligned with the findings on Cu/AC catalysts modified with alkaline earth metal additives [61]. The modification with Ca and Sr reduced the size of Cu species and improved the dispersion, which led to more selective hydrogenation pathway toward MG. These experimental results highlighted that the critical role of optimizing Cu size in modulating the reaction pathways in DMO hydrogenation. In fact, the deposited Cu active species may have a wide range of size distribution, not limited to the Cun/CeO2 (n = 1–8, and 14) investigated in this work. We proposed to use a simplified model of spherical segment to present a rough estimation on the optimal size of Cu on CeO2 for the catalyst design [62]. The radius of curvature R and contact angle θ are essential parameters for describing a supported particle, as shown in Fig. 5 a. For the Cu/CeO2 with an electronic metal-support interaction (EMSI), the contact angle θ exceeds π/2, and consequently the d and h are correlated as d = 2 h 1 - c o s θ (3π/2 ≥ θ > π/2), when the cluster size is small but not a highly dispersed monolayer. Using this equation and assuming the contact angle window of (3π/2, π/2), we can calculate the size of the quasi-two-layer Cu clusters to be 0.45–0.70 nm, if estimating according to the Cu6/CeO2 model (h = 3.54 Å). For the bigger Cu deposits, the θ is less than π/2 and the corresponding the d and h are correlated as d = 2 h s i n θ 1 - c o s θ . For instance, the particle size is larger than 0.75 nm by using Cu8/CeO2 model (h = 3.78 Å) for calculation. Consequently, it can be obtained that the deposited Cu with the size from single atom to 0.7 nm is predicted to favor the DMO selective hydrogenation to MG. The calculated size and morphology of the copper clusters proposed in this study strongly correlated to the experimental observations [20]. Experimentally, it was reported that under 100 % DMO conversion, Cu clusters of 0.42 nm measured by HAADF-STEM exhibited a ridge-like morphology and achieved MG selectivity as high as 95 %, while increasing the cluster size to 0.78 nm induced the rapid decline in MG selectivity to 68 % [20]. It is surprisingly agreed with the dimensions of the Cu4/CeO2 model (0.45 nm) and Cu8/CeO2 model (0.75 nm) here. The above studies on DMO hydrogenation consistently reveal that the activity and selectivity toward MG are closely influenced by the size of Cu deposit, where catalysts with ridge-like morphology and dual active sites (Cu0-Cuδ+) exhibit superior semi-hydrogenation performance. This is attributed to the significant difference (ΔE) between the energy barrier for further hydrogenation and the desorption energy of MG (Fig. 5b). 4 Conclusion This study demonstrates that Cu cluster size and structure significantly influence the activity and selectivity in DMO hydrogenation. The Cu4 clusters with a “ridge-like” morphology and dual active sites (Cu0-Cuδ+) exhibited the best performance. The synergy between Cu0 and Cuδ+ sites play a critical role in the changing adsorption configurations of intermediates during the catalytic process. Small Cu clusters exhibit a strong electronic effect, where the empty d orbitals of Cu with high oxidation state form donor–acceptor interactions with the π orbitals of CO in MG. In contrast, larger clusters primarily display a steric hindrance, inducing a downward-directed configuration of acyl species, which reduces the Pauli repulsion in the transition state of MG dissociation, and promotes further hydrogenation of MG to EG. The optimal Cu cluster size with a ridge-like morphology provides an ideal structure by allowing sufficient Cu0-Cuδ+ site interactions and achieving high MG selectivity in the semi-hydrogenation of DMO. These findings offer a strategic framework for advancing Cu-supported catalysts in various selective hydrogenation applications, particularly where minimizing over-hydrogenation is essential for intermediate production. coredata.dc:description: Identification the size dependence behavior of copper active species are crucial for achieving semi-hydrogenation of carbon–oxygen bonds in the symmetric-structured molecules. Semi-hydrogenation of dimethyl oxalate (DMO) was used as typical for investigation, providing a promising pathway for the production of methyl glycolate (MG), an important feedstock for high value-added materials. Here, by employing a theoretical study, we elucidated the structure-sensitivity and emphasized the vital role of electronic and geometric structure in the reaction mechanism over Cun/CeO2 catalysts. The Cu4 cluster with a “ridge-like” structure and dual sites (Cu0-Cuδ+) exhibited the best performance for semi-hydrogenation of DMO to MG, agreed with the experimental results. Electronic structure of small Cu clusters influences MG selectivity by affecting the strength of donor–acceptor interactions between empty d orbitals of Cu and the π orbitals of CO group. In contrast, steric hindrance induces a downward-directed configuration of acyl species on larger Cu clusters, reducing the Pauli repulsion in the transition state of MG dissociation, and promoting undesired further hydrogenation of MG. Our findings provided a rational guideline for designing catalysts with optimal particle size and morphology in the semi-hydrogenation of symmetric-structured molecules.
